column14: and floating bottles from the wardroom. Yet this stretch of sea was itself in motion. Whenever he could take a good noon observation or a double amplitude

Like every other sailor he had heard of ships in the doldrums lying helpless for weeks and even months
column18: eating their stores and accumulating weed; he had had severe experience of it himself; and as he examined the sky

column1: 12:00|noon|"No one had to wake the Captain this time. He was on the quarterdeck well before sunrise

column5: steering a course that would cut his own in a few hours' time. Jack brought the wind upon his starboard beam; the Dutchman did the same
column6: but no more - he did not attempt to close. And so they ran all day through the rain
column7: running parallel courses
column8: south and south. Now and then a squall would hide one from the other
column9: but every time it cleared
column10: there was the Waakzaamheid
column11: keeping station as faithfully as if she were the Leopard's consort

column14: but by nightfall they were at much the same distance apart
column15: having run off a hundred and thirty miles by dead reckoning - no sight of the sun at noon
column16: with all that driving cloud. After dark Jack began beating up
column19: hoping to shake off the Waakzaamheid
column20: which was not such a windward ship

column23: had not the wind failed him

column1: 12:00|noon|"They had been south of forty degrees since Thursday
column2: and although at this season
column3: the beginning of the austral summer
column4: even the westerlies were not quite to be relied on north of forty-five or even forty-six
column5: they had proved true enough for the Leopard
column6: and together with the current they had carried her over two hundred nautical miles between one noon observation and the next day after day
column7: with never a glimpse of the Waakzaamheid."|"Desolation Island"|"Patrick O'Brian"

column1: ap 08:00|eight|"The graveyard watch wore on
column2: bell by bell; and still they ran
column3: starting neither sheet nor tack
column4: an eager
column5: grim
column6: and most determined pursuit. At eight bells
column7: with both watches on deck
column8: he took in the spritsail
column9: got the yard fore and aft
column10: set the inner jib
column11: and bore up another point. It might be his last chance of doing so
column12: for the air was now filled with flying water and the ship was tearing through the sea at a rate he never would have believed possible
column13: a rate that in fact would have been impossible without those hawsers to the mastheads. But this was no longer the exhilarating pace of a few hours ago; now there was a nightmare
column14: breakneck quality about it; and now the wind was blowing very hard indeed."|"Desolation Island"|"Patrick O'Brian"

column1: ap > 07:00|"just after seven"|"Hour after hour towards the morning watch
column2: and hour after hour the wind increased. Twice
column3: just after seven bells
column4: the Leopard was very nearly pooped by a freakish bursting sea: the steady progression of the rollers was losing its regularity
column5: becoming disordered. Eight bells again
column6: and he put the ship before the wind
column7: taking in the staysails. It was impossible to get an accurate reading of the log
column8: for the blast tossed the log-boat forward of her bows; and now the carpenter's mate reported two foot of water in the well. The Leopard had been working and straining so much that a good deal had come in through her sides
column9: let alone that which made its way down from the decks in spite of the laid hatches and through the hawse-holes in spite of the bags."|"Desolation Island"|"Patrick O'Brian"

column5: driving it forward in a grey veil that darkened and filled the air. The Waakzaamheid lay within two miles. And now the extreme danger of sailing in a very heavy swell became more and more apparent; in the troughs
column6: the valleys between the waves

column10: she lost some of her way at the bottom
column11: whereas she needed all her speed to outrun the following seas
column12: for if they were to overtake her she would be pooped
column13: smothered in a mass of breaking water. Then ten to one she would slew round and broach to
column14: presenting her broadside to the wind
column15: so that the next sea would overwhelm her."|"Desolation Island"|"Patrick O'Brian"

column1: 00:00|midnight|"The sea mounted
column2: the wind blew stronger; men were sent all along the lee-scuppers to keep them clear and help the water over the side. But at last the hatch had to be battened down
column3: and the lightening of the ship grew harder still. At midnight the cleverer hands were called from the pumps
column4: and they set to in the waist
column5: plying needle and palm by lantern-light
column6: sewing rolls of oakum to a studding-sail that was to be passed under the ship's bottom to stop the leak; but still the pumps whirled on and on
column7: and in time the night assumed an everlasting quality - heaving round the winch
column8: poising on the roll in the darkness to thrust with all one's force
column9: was all that mattered in the world. At one point there was a general cheer at the report that the larboard chain-pump was sucking
column10: but they did not stop for a moment: and although the report proved false - it was only a temporary blocking of the channel -the cry itself was encouraging."|"Desolation Island"|"Patrick O'Brian"

column1: 12:00|noon|"The question of steering had of course been of the first importance from the moment the Leopard had lost her rudder
column2: but these last few days it was even more present to his mind than usual. At any moment now the Crozet islands might heave in sight
column3: and to reach them he must be able to manoeuvre the ship. Just when they might appear he could not tell: in the first place he had little confidence in the longitude laid down by their French discoverer
column4: and in the second his chronometers had been overturned in the drunken turmoil when the boats put off
column5: so that he had only his hack-watch for his position. However
column6: neither he nor the Frenchman could be far out in the latitude
column7: and he had been keeping the Leopard as near to 46°45'S as ever he could
column8: though with these covered skies he could rarely make a noon observation. And for days now
column9: in spite of the shortage of hands
column10: the sharpest eyes in the ship had been at the masthead."|"Desolation Island"|"Patrick O'Brian"

column1: 03:00|"three in the morning"|"And tight they slept indeed
column2: so tight that Stephen
column3: roused out at three in the morning for his spell at the starboard chain-pump
column4: was first unable to find his way to that familiar post until the drooping midshipman whom he was to relieve led him there by hand
column5: and then powerless to reconstitute the events of yesterday until he had been heaving for half an hour - until the exercise and the steady half-freezing rain had dispelled the fumes of that trance-like sleep."|"Desolation Island"|"Patrick O'Brian"
